fields.description:
*Background*
It was discovered on support that there are Mongo metrics missing from some Mongo replica sets. The missing metrics include primary.primary, among others, and the metric is intermittent for some replica sets, is missing for others and is available on some others.

*Notes*
# See [here|https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1tNUAD9v2pStkzC6xqvuus8abGJPBL8KSFfw7fKEeCas/edit#gid=0] for current observed behaviour across replicasets
# There are new metrics that we don't currently deal with.
# Consider a little constant gardening here - in Grafana the replicasets we decommissioned are still selectable in the drop-down lists.

*Acceptance Criteria*
# We see expected metrics for all MongoDB replicasets

fields.description:
*Background*
We have AWS Advanced Shield for DDoS response, we also have per-IP rate limits (which kick in within a few minutes).

However, AWS Advanced Shield is not instantaneous and there will be a period of time during a DDoS attack where the Platform is receiving a lot of requests. We can imagine this overwhelming the log pipeline, making understanding what is going on difficult or impossible as log ingestion time increases.

Let's work out what we could do to mitigate against this while maintaining effective observability with Telemetry and anyone else we need.

*Notes*
# This will need collaboration with Telemetry and please to bring in Edd as needed too
# Hint: Please engage with AWS who will have guidance
# We currently have a Route53 health check endpoint that AWS Advanced Shield uses to notify AWS that we are in trouble and need a response. Consider whether we should factor other Platform metrics into this health check. For example, some Telemetry health indicators.
# Consider whether AWS Advanced Shield responses to mitigate against a DDoS attack would also contribute to log load (e.g. logging blocks which add to log quantity)
# We also have AWS Shield (standard)

*Spike Question*
# How do we protect the Platform logging and metrics pipelines when we receive abnormally high numbers of requests into ISC

*Acceptance Criteria*
# Outcome of the spike question is written up in this ticket or linked to this ticket
# The outcome is presented to the team and the outcome write-up modified as needed
# Follow-on tickets to make this happen are written up and linked to this ticket

fields.summary: What does disaster-resilient S3 storage for Object Store look like?

issuetype.description: Created by Jira Software - do not edit or delete. Issue type for a user story.
issuetype.name: Story

fields.description:
*Background*

During INFRA-6958, we looked into how to improve the resilience of the S3 storage used by the _object-store_ μserivce. We determined that it would be best to implement {*}versioning{*}.

INFRA-6958 states that we should ensure that access to backup objects will not be routine. In order to achieve this, we determined that access to previous versions should be restricted to this role: [RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess|https://github.com/hmrc/aws-users/blob/main/cfstacks/templates/IAMStacks/common/webops/role_s3_emergency_data_access]

*Notes*
 # We have created Terraform code for a [proof of concept|https://github.com/hmrc/webops-terraform/blob/master/components/buckets/mdtp-versioned-object-storage.tf]
 ## A lifecycle policy is set up to expire versions after 31 days

*Acceptance criteria*
 # The object-store service uses s3 storage which has versioning enabled
 # Versions must only be retained for 31 days.
 # Only [RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess|https://github.com/hmrc/aws-users/blob/main/cfstacks/templates/IAMStacks/common/webops/role_s3_emergency_data_access] has access to previous version of objects
 # {{ManagedPolicyWebopsEngineeringPermissionsBoundary}} denies {{s3:DeleteObjectVersion}} for the {{mdtp-oss-*}} buckets
 # {{ManagedPolicyWebopsProvisionerPermissionsBoundary}} denies {{s3:DeleteObjectVersion}} for the {{mdtp-oss-*}} buckets
 # {{RoleInterimPlatformDeity}} and {{RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess}} explicitly deny {{s3:DeleteObjectVersion}} for the {{mdtp-oss-*}} buckets
 # A runbook exists that a human can follow to restore a previous version of an object
fields.summary: The object-store service uses disaster-resilient S3 storage

items.fromString:
*Background*
As part of INFRA-6958 we looked into how to make the s3 storage used by the object-store micro-serivce to be more resilient. We decided that versioning should be enabled and we should replicate objects to a backup bucket with a 31 day retention period.

*Notes*
We have created two buckets in integration called:
object-store-<md5 sum of account id>
object-store-backup-<md5 sum of account id>
The buckets we have created have versioning and replication enabled.
We need to ensure the object-store service can use the new configuration before changing anything else.

*Acceptance criteria*
* The object-store service uses a versioned and replicated backup bucket

items.toString:
*Background*
 As part of INFRA-6958 we looked into how to make the s3 storage used by the object-store μserivce to be more resilient. We decided that versioning should be enabled and we should replicate objects to a backup bucket with a fixed 31 day retention period.

In INFRA-6958, we discussed how we could ensure that access to backup objects would not be routine. We determined that access to previous versions and replicated objects should be restricted to its own IAM user.

 

*Notes*
 * We have created two buckets in integration called:
 **  object-store-<md5 sum of account id>
 ** object-store-backup-<md5 sum of account id>
 * The buckets we have created have versioning and replication enabled.
 * We need to ensure the object-store service can use the new configuration before changing anything else.

*Acceptance criteria*
 * The object-store service uses a versioned and replicated backup bucket

items.fromString:
*Background*
 As part of INFRA-6958 we looked into how to make the s3 storage used by the object-store μserivce to be more resilient. We decided that versioning should be enabled and we should replicate objects to a backup bucket with a fixed 31 day retention period.

In INFRA-6958, we discussed how we could ensure that access to backup objects would not be routine. We determined that access to previous versions and replicated objects should be restricted to its own IAM user.

 

*Notes*
 * We have created two buckets in integration called:
 **  object-store-<md5 sum of account id>
 ** object-store-backup-<md5 sum of account id>
 * The buckets we have created have versioning and replication enabled.
 * We need to ensure the object-store service can use the new configuration before changing anything else.

*Acceptance criteria*
 * The object-store service uses a versioned and replicated backup bucket
 * Access to replicated and versioned data is restricted to a role with special protected (e.g. it could raise an alert whenever it is assumed).

*Background*

During INFRA-6958, we looked into how to improve the resilience of the S3 storage used by the _object-store_ μserivce. After the discussion we determined that it would be best to implement *versioning* as well as *replicating* data to a backup bucket.

INFRA-6958 states that we should ensure that access to backup objects will not be routine. In order to achieve this, we determined that access to previous versions and replicated objects should be restricted to its own IAM user.

*Notes*
 * We have created two buckets in integration called:
 **  object-store-<md5 sum of account id>
 ** object-store-backup-<md5 sum of account id>
 * The buckets we have created have versioning and replication enabled.
 * We need to ensure the object-store service can use the new configuration before changing anything else.

*Acceptance criteria*
 * The object-store service uses a versioned and replicated backup bucket that is retained for 31 days.
 * Access to replicated and versioned data is restricted to a role with special protections (e.g. it could raise an alert whenever it is assumed).

items.toString:
*Background*

During INFRA-6958, we looked into how to improve the resilience of the S3 storage used by the _object-store_ μserivce. After the discussion we determined that it would be best to implement *versioning* as well as *replicating* data to a backup bucket.

INFRA-6958 states that we should ensure that access to backup objects will not be routine. In order to achieve this, we determined that access to previous versions and replicated objects should be restricted to its own IAM user.

*Notes*
 # We have created two new buckets in integration called:
 **  object-store-<md5 sum of account id>
 *** Using this bucket would require PlatOps to change or reconfigure _object-store._ Consider if it is best to continue using this name or to reconfigure the _mdtp-oss_ bucket.
 ** object-store-backup-<md5 sum of account id>
 # The buckets we have created have versioning and replication enabled.
 # We need to ensure the object-store service can use the new configuration before changing anything else.
 # It may be better to split this ticket into two,
 ## the first to enable *versioning*
 ## the second (which would be blocked by the first) would be to enable *replication*
 # Whilst we do want a versioned and replicated backup bucket to exist, we do not want _object-store_ to have access to it.

*Acceptance criteria*
 # The object-store service uses a versioned and replicated backup bucket.
 # Objects within the backup bucket are retained for 31 days.
 # Access to replicated and versioned data is restricted to a role with special protections (e.g. it could raise an alert whenever it is assumed).

During INFRA-6958, we looked into how to improve the resilience of the S3 storage used by the _object-store_ μserivce. After the discussion we determined that it would be best to implement *versioning* as well as *replicating* data to a backup bucket.

INFRA-6958 states that we should ensure that access to backup objects will not be routine. In order to achieve this, we determined that access to previous versions and replicated objects should be restricted to this role: [RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess|https://github.com/hmrc/aws-users/blob/main/cfstacks/templates/IAMStacks/common/webops/role_s3_emergency_data_access]
*Notes*
 # We have created Terraform code for a [proof of concept|https://github.com/hmrc/webops-terraform/blob/master/components/buckets/mdtp-versioned-object-storage.tf]
 # Using a new bucket would require PlatOps to change or reconfigure _object-store._ Consider if it is best to use a new bucket or to reconfigure the _mdtp-oss_ bucket.
 # We need to ensure the object-store service can use the new configuration before changing anything else.
 #Consider whether it is better to split this ticket into two and create a follow on ticket to configure replication once the versioning is enabled

*Acceptance criteria*
 # The object-store service uses a versioned and replicated backup bucket.
 # Objects within the backup bucket are retained for 31 days.
 # Access to replicated and versioned data is restricted to a role with special protections (e.g. it could raise an alert whenever it is assumed).

*Background*

During INFRA-6958, we looked into how to improve the resilience of the S3 storage used by the _object-store_ μserivce. After the discussion we determined that it would be best to implement *versioning* as well as *replicating* data to a backup bucket.

INFRA-6958 states that we should ensure that access to backup objects will not be routine. In order to achieve this, we determined that access to previous versions and replicated objects should be restricted to this role: [RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess|https://github.com/hmrc/aws-users/blob/main/cfstacks/templates/IAMStacks/common/webops/role_s3_emergency_data_access]

*Notes*
 # We have created Terraform code for a [proof of concept|https://github.com/hmrc/webops-terraform/blob/master/components/buckets/mdtp-versioned-object-storage.tf]
 # Using a new bucket would require PlatOps to change or reconfigure _object-store._ Consider if it is best to use a new bucket or to reconfigure the _mdtp-oss_ bucket.
 # Consider whether it is better to split this ticket into two and create a follow on ticket to configure replication once the versioning is enabled.


*Acceptance criteria*

 # If replication to a backup bucket is configured during this ticket then backup objects are only retained for 31 days.

 # `ManagedPolicyWebopsEngineeringPermissionsBoundary` denies `s3:DeleteObjectVersion` for the `mdtp-oss-*` buckets
 # `RoleInfrastructureAdministrator`, RoleInterimPlatformDeity` and `RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess` explicitly deny `s3:DeleteObjectVersion` for the `mdtp-oss-*` buckets
items.toString:
*Background*

During INFRA-6958, we looked into how to improve the resilience of the S3 storage used by the _object-store_ μserivce. We determined that it would be best to implement {*}versioning{*}.

INFRA-6958 states that we should ensure that access to backup objects will not be routine. In order to achieve this, we determined that access to previous versions should be restricted to this role: [RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess|https://github.com/hmrc/aws-users/blob/main/cfstacks/templates/IAMStacks/common/webops/role_s3_emergency_data_access]

*Notes*
 # We have created Terraform code for a [proof of concept|https://github.com/hmrc/webops-terraform/blob/master/components/buckets/mdtp-versioned-object-storage.tf]
 ## A lifecycle policy is set up to expire versions after 31 days

*Acceptance criteria*
 # The object-store service uses s3 storage which has versioning enabled
 # Versions must only be retained for 31 days.
 # Only [RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess|https://github.com/hmrc/aws-users/blob/main/cfstacks/templates/IAMStacks/common/webops/role_s3_emergency_data_access] has access to previous version of objects
 # {{ManagedPolicyWebopsEngineeringPermissionsBoundary}} denies {{s3:DeleteObjectVersion}} for the {{mdtp-oss-*}} buckets
 # {{ManagedPolicyWebopsProvisionerPermissionsBoundary}} denies {{s3:DeleteObjectVersion}} for the {{mdtp-oss-*}} buckets
 # {{RoleInterimPlatformDeity}} and {{RoleS3EmergencyDataAccess}} explicitly deny {{s3:DeleteObjectVersion}} for the {{mdtp-oss-*}} buckets

fields.description:
*Background*
We need to migrate away from Akamai managed DNS to migrate away from Akamai. 
Akamai currently hosts a secondary zone that serves as authoritative DNS for public queries.

INFRA-7130 decided that Amazon Route 53 is the most appropriate alternative, but we need to know how we'll migrate from current to desired state.

Akamai is used to provide DDoS protection for the DNS.
We don't want to replicate the current primary/secondary setup that Fujitsu and Akamai have as we're also going to be moving away from Fujitsu entirely.

*Notes*
# At kick-off decide which environments we need non-MDTP DNS configuration in.
# Protecting Our Brand Online sam.nel@hmrc.gov.uk and craig.pounder@hmrc.gov.uk

*Acceptance Criteria*
# We have a dedicated repository for non-MDTP DNS configuration
# We have a dedicated pipeline to apply non-MDTP DNS configuration
# Protecting our Brand know to inform us of any changes to the {{visitukheritage.gov.uk}} zone.
# Infrastructure engineers can propose changes, but need another engineers approval to merge
# A zone exists in Route 53 for {{{}visitukheritage.gov.uk{}}}, but it is not authoritative.
fields.summary: We non-authoritatively manage visitukheritage.gov.uk in Route 53

items.toString: This issue is blocked by INFRA-7130

items.fromString:
*Background*

We need to migrate away from Akamai managed DNS to migrate away from Akamai. 

Akamai currently host a secondary zone that serves as authoritative DNS for public queries. INFRA-7130 decided that Amazon Route 53 is the most appropriate alternative, but we need to know how we'll migrate from the current state to the ideal.

Akamai is used to provide DDoS protection for the DNS.

*Notes*
 # Consider if we can simply migrate primary/secondary zones to Route 53, or if we need Akamai for any special functions (e.g. does Akamai have the equivalent of Route 53 ALIAS records?)
 # Rough ideas of how long (days/weeks/months) each step in the migration would take would be useful.

*Spike Question*
 # How do we migrate from Akamai DNS to MDTP managed DNS?

*Acceptance Criteria*
 # Outcome of the spike question is written up in this ticket or linked to this ticket
 # The outcome is presented to the team and the outcome write-up modified as needed
 # LDD is updated with the outcome
 # Follow-on tickets to make this happen are written up and linked to this ticket

 # This ticket is to implement the outcome from INFRA-7130.

*Acceptance Criteria*
 # A zone exists in Route 53 for {{{}visitukheritage.gov.uk{}}}, but it is not authoritative.
items.toString:
*Background*
We need to migrate away from Akamai managed DNS to migrate away from Akamai. 
Akamai currently hosts a secondary zone that serves as authoritative DNS for public queries.

INFRA-7130 decided that Amazon Route 53 is the most appropriate alternative, but we need to know how we'll migrate from the current state to the ideal.

Akamai is used to provide DDoS protection for the DNS.
We don't want to replicate the current primary/secondary setup that Fujitsu and Akamai have as we're also going to be moving away from Fujitsu entirely.

*Notes*
 # At kick-off decide which environments we need non-MDTP DNS configuration in.

*Acceptance Criteria*
 # We have a dedicated repository for non-MDTP DNS configuration
 # We have a dedicated pipeline to apply non-MDTP DNS configuration
 # Protecting our Brand know to inform us of any changes to the {{visitukheritage.gov.uk}} zone.
 # Infrastructure engineers can propose changes, but need another engineers approval to merge
 # A zone exists in Route 53 for {{{}visitukheritage.gov.uk{}}}, but it is not authoritative.

fields.description:
*Background*
App Proxies are redundant with the move to ECS.

The {{protected app proxy}} is still used for some translation for requests routed via API Platform ({{public-api-proxy}}) but we can fulfill this need another way.
This ticket concerns everything _except_ protected app proxy and the _build app proxy_

*Notes*
# The complete list of app proxies to get rid of are:
## public
## public-rate
## protected-rate
## public-monolith
# Any associated infrastructure also needs to go, like:
## LBs
## per-zone wildcard DNS records (if they are not used by anything else e.g. protected app proxy)
## anything else...
# For inspiration, [partial work|https://jira.tools.tax.service.gov.uk/browse/INFRA-7136?focusedCommentId=1467543&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-1467543] by Jason

*Acceptance Criteria*
 # No App Proxies ((except protected app proxy and build app proxy) exist in any environment
 # No associated infrastructure (including app servers, &c.) exists in any environment
 # All associated Infrastructure-as-Code has been deleted or archived
